However, I will now rely on the Buddha's spiritual power, wishing to cause the minds of those who are disciplined and can be taught to quickly become pure, wishing to cause the minds of those who cultivate wholesome roots to attain mastery, to proclaim and explain for you according to your questions.

At that time, the night spirit who delights in universal peace and the blossoming of all tree flowers, wishing to reiterate this meaning, contemplated the realm of the tathÄgatas of the three times and spoke a verse, saying:
The question you ask now, O Buddha's disciple, is about the buddhas' boundless, profound realm,
Even if one were to expound for dust-mote-like eons in buddha-realms as numerous as dust motes, one still could not fully describe it.
Those who are evil, greedy, angry, deluded, arrogant, ignorant, and obscured by afflictions,
Those whose minds are bound by defilements and entanglements, cannot know the buddhas' tranquil Dharma.
Those whose minds are deceitful, turbulent, and always attached to stinginess and jealousy,
Those bound by the ropes of afflictive actions, cannot understand the buddhas' realm.
Those who are attached to the aggregates, elements, and sense bases, whose minds always cling to the view of self,
Those whose minds, thoughts, and views are inverted, cannot enter the TathÄgata's ground of quiescence.
The buddhas' realm is tranquil, profound, and of the nature of true permanence, free from discrimination,
Those attached to existence and birth-and-death cannot enter this impartial Dharma of non-reliance.
Born into the family lineage of the buddhas, always protected by all tathÄgatas,
Those who uphold the teachings of the Dharma King, this is the realm of the wisdom eye of the sages.
Those who are close to true and good spiritual friends, who delight in the pure Dharma without being content,
Who single-mindedly seek the Buddha's power and receive the Dharma cloud, they will rejoice upon hearing this Dharma.
The mind is always pure and free from discrimination, not attached to anything like empty space,
The lamp of wisdom is sovereign in destroying ignorance, this is the realm of the stainless ones.
With great compassion covering the world, pervading the ocean of sentient beings in the three times,
Benefiting and gladdening without bound, this is the realm of the deeply practicing ones.
The mind is always joyful and free from attachment, able to give up all that one has,
Delighting in speaking equally and bestowing upon sentient beings, this is the realm of the unattached.
The mind is free from defilement and leaves behind faults, ultimately disciplined and free from worry or regret,
In accordance with the Buddha's teachings, they are able to cultivate completely, this is the realm of the stainless ones.
The mind is without agitation or discrimination, able to universally awaken to the nature of all dharmas,
Far removed from all afflictions and karma, this is the realm of the liberated ones.
The mind is without fatigue or weariness, always without regression, courageously and diligently cultivating omniscience,
Abiding in the supreme pure precepts, this is the realm of the great beings.
The mind deeply enters various samÄdhis, ultimately cool and refreshing without vexation,
Having already cultivated the causes of the ocean of omniscience, this is the liberation of the tranquil ones.
Understanding the distinguishing characteristics of all dharmas, skillfully entering the boundless profound Dharma realm,
Universally delivering all beings without remainder, this is the liberation of the lamp of wisdom.
Understanding the true nature of sentient beings, not attached to the ocean of existences,
Like a reflection appearing in the water of the mind, this is the liberation of the forerunner.
Born from the ocean of buddhas of the three times, skillful means, vows, and seeds,
Exhausting all kalpas and lands, diligently practicing, this is the liberation of Samantabhadra.
Universally entering all Dharma realm gates, fully seeing the ocean of lands in the ten directions,
Also seeing the formation and destruction of kalpas therein, this is the realm of the non-dual.
In the atoms of the ocean of lands in the ten directions, seeing the Buddha sitting under the bodhi tree,
Attaining perfect enlightenment and transforming beings, this is the realm of the unobstructed eye.
You, for an ocean of immeasurable great kalpas, have closely attended and served the good and wise advisors,
For the sake of benefiting beings and seeking the true Dharma, having heard it, you have remembered it without forgetting.
The vast realm of Vairocana is boundless, immeasurable, and difficult to conceive,
I will explain for you by the Buddha's power, Causing your profound mind to become pure.
Good sons!

In the distant past, beyond as many kalpas as there are atoms in a world ocean, there was a world ocean called Vairocana Ocean of Real Gold Maá¹‡i Mountain. In that world ocean, a Buddha appeared called Universal Illumination of the Dharma Realm Wisdom Mountain, King of Tranquil Virtue.
Good sons!

When that Buddha was cultivating the bodhisattva path in the past, he was able to universally purify that ocean of worlds. In that ocean of worlds there were as many types of worlds as there are atoms in a buddha-land, and in each world there were as many eons as there are atoms in a world. In each eon, innumerable buddhas appeared in the world. In each eon, the buddhas expounded as many sÅ«tras as there are atoms in an ocean of worlds. In each sÅ«tra, they gave predictions to as many bodhisattvas as there are atoms in a buddha-land. Good man!
In that ocean of worlds of the mountain of genuine gold and maá¹‡i jewels of Vairocana, there is a type of world called Adorned Banner Manifesting All Gates.

In this world system there was a world called Universal Light of Auspicious Radiance of All Jewels, made of the king of jewels reflecting the images of all transformed Buddhas, shaped like a celestial city;
adorned with the king of jewels reflecting the sites of enlightenment of all Tathagatas, situated above the ocean of all jewel lotus flowers, a mixture of pure and impure.
In this world there were as many four-continent worlds as there are atoms in Mount Sumeru. In the center of one four-continent world was a four-continent world called Banner of All Jewel Mountains;
each of the four continents was immeasurable hundreds of thousands of yojanas in length and breadth, each with ten thousand great cities;

in the Jambudvipa continent there was a royal capital called Adorned with Wonderful Jewels and Sala Trees, with ten thousand great cities as its retinue, surrounding it. The lifespan of the people of Jambudvipa was ten thousand years.

At that time, there was a wheel-turning king named All-Dharma-Complete-Jewel-Canopy-Great-Lion-Roar-Sound. That king had five hundred ministers, sixty thousand concubines, and seven hundred princes. The princes were all endowed with excellent appearance, were brave and valiant, and had great power.
At that time, the king's majestic virtue pervaded the entire JambudvÄ«pa, without any enemies.

At that time, at the end of the eon of that world, the five turbidities arose. All the people had short lifespans, few resources, and ugly appearances. Whether walking, standing, sitting, or lying down, they experienced much suffering and little joy. They did not cultivate the ten wholesome deeds but exclusively engaged in evil actions. They quarreled with each other, competed with each other, deceived each other, spoke insincerely, caused division among others, spoke harshly, envied the good fortune of others, and greedily sought unlawfully, deeply entering the dense forest of the evil net.

For this reason, the wind and rain are untimely, the crops do not ripen, the medicinal trees, flowers, gardens, forests, grasses and trees all wither and die, clothing and food are in short supply, there are many epidemics, they run in all directions, having no one to rely on, all coming together to surround the great city of the capital, countless, boundless hundreds of thousands of myriads of millions, on all four sides, crying out in loud voices.

Some raised both hands, some joined their palms, some beat their heads on the ground, some raised their hands to beat their chests, some bent their knees and wailed for a long time, some jumped up and shouted loudly, their hair disheveled, their clothes tattered and dirty, their skin cracked and their faces lusterless.

Great King!

We are now poor, orphaned, exposed, hungry, thirsty, cold, sick, weak, and oppressed by various sufferings. We are in a state of extreme distress, both physically and mentally. Our lives are not long, we have no one to rely on, no one to save us, and no one to whom we can appeal. We are like those in prison, with the signs of death appearing before us.

We now come to take refuge in the great king. We observe that the great king is benevolent and wise. We have the thought of obtaining peace and happiness from the great king, the thought of compassion, the thought of love and respect, the thought of body and life, the thought of being accepted, the thought of a treasure trove, the thought of encountering a ferry, the thought of encountering a road, the thought of encountering a boat, the thought of seeing a treasure island, the thought of obtaining wealth and profit, the thought of ascending to the heavenly palace, the thought of leaving enemies behind, and the thought of extinguishing all suffering.'

At that time, the great king, having heard these words, attained a hundred thousand asaá¹ƒkhyeya gates of great compassion. With single-minded thought, he contemplated and observed, and uttered ten kinds of words of great compassion.
What are the ten?
They are:
Alas!
Sentient beings fall into the bottomless abyss of birth and death. How can I quickly rescue them, help them escape, and enable them to abide in the TathÄgata's ground of omniscience?
Alas!
Sentient beings are oppressed by afflictions, tormenting their bodies and minds. How can I become their protector and help them abide in various wholesome practices?
Alas!

Sentient beings are always terrified by birth, old age, sickness, and death. How can I become their refuge, free them from bondage and attachment, and enable them to attain the peace and security of body and mind forever?
Alas!

Sentient beings are always oppressed by various terrors in the world, afflicting their bodies. How can I become their savior, help them escape all calamities and difficulties, and enable them to abide in the TathÄgata's path of omniscience?
Alas!

Sentient beings are without the eye of wisdom, always covered by the doubts and views of self-existence. How can I make expedient means for them, enabling them to remove the cataracts of doubt and views?
Alas!

Sentient beings are always confused by ignorance and darkness, far from wholesome dharmas. How can I be a torch of wisdom for them, illuminating their ignorance, enabling them to clearly see the city of omniscience and ultimately attain liberation?
Alas!

Sentient beings are always confused by various kinds of stinginess, jealousy, flattery, and deception, causing their minds to be turbid and disturbed. How can I enlighten them, enabling them to realize the pure Dharma body?
Alas!

Sentient beings are adrift for a long time in the great ocean of birth and death in all worlds. How can I be a boat and raft for them, transporting them everywhere, enabling them to enter the ocean of omniscience?
Alas!

Sentient beings have stubborn faculties and are far from the unsurpassed great teacher who tames them. In all worlds, there is no one who can tame them. How can I tame them, enabling them to mature all wholesome roots and possess the great majestic spiritual powers of the TathÄgata?
Alas!
Sentient beings are like the blind, not seeing the right path. They follow the crooked paths. How can I open the wisdom-eye for them, lead them, and enable them to enter the gate of omniscience?

This great bodhisattva diligently cultivates various practices, seeks omniscience, and vows to benefit all
sentient beings without becoming weary. He vows to provide all sentient beings with clothing and food,
and to attain the immeasurable wonderful bliss of enlightenment. He abandons all unwholesome thoughts and always vows to

At that time, the woman gave rise to the thought of the great teacher towards the king, the thought of the most supreme good and wise advisor, the thought of compassion, the thought of being able to accept and embrace, her mind was upright, most pure, and she gave rise to a mind of vast joy.
